originalText.plaidHtml: This is the most real and the best spy thriller i watched till now. The cinematography, direction, screenplay, acting everything was awesome. If you are comfortable to watch the horrific truth this is the movie you should watch. If you want to be in delusion you don't need to watch this. Keep watching old style ISI glorifying and RAW-ISI matrimonial spy thrillers.

summary.originalText: This is must watch Theatrical Experience

originalText.plaidHtml:
Went into Dhurandhar expecting a hard-hitting spy thriller, and on many counts, the film delivers. Director Aditya Dhar builds a violent, morally charged world inspired by real-life events, giving the story solid weight. The performances are the film's biggest strength-Ranveer Singh brings fierce intensity and carries the narrative whenever the stakes rise, while Akshaye Khanna and R. Madhavan add depth and gravitas to the drama. Visually, the gritty cinematography, realistic action, and strong background score make it a compelling big-screen experience.

That said, the film isn't without flaws. Its lengthy 3h 32m runtime leads to slower stretches, especially in the middle, which may test the patience of viewers expecting a tighter thriller. While the ambitious eight-chapter structure mostly works, a sharper edit could have elevated the impact. Overall, Dhurandhar is a bold and intense watch that largely hits its mark-imperfect, but worth experiencing for fans of hard-edged spy thrillers.

Performance is excellent and Movie is very close to reality. Nobody has ever shown such a brutal reality of (you know who). Ranveer has performed well as he always done. Its Shows covert operations, espionage and betrayals just as any other national Security based movie would but It showed ground based reality of how things really on other side of border.

originalText.plaidHtml: Reels and Reality are in perfect Harmony...Waiting for Part- 2,3......n. Indian intelligence wings must be appreciated for their covert operations and protecting the National Security. India not only fought 2.5 front war, there has been so many unseen front where India is still suffering. So this time of movies builds confidence in our forces (Internally as well as Externally). Jai Hind.

summary.originalText: One of the bestt movie of bollywood.. Must watch

originalText.plaidHtml:
Dhurandhar is honestly one of the best Bollywood movies I've seen in a long time. Cinematically, the film is on another level. Every shot looks well planned and visually strong.

The sound design and background score are insane. It adds so much impact to the scenes and keeps you completely engaged throughout the movie.

All the actors have done an amazing job. No overacting, no weak performances - every character feels real and powerful in their own way.

Direction is solid and confident, and the movie never feels boring. Dhurandhar is not just a film, it's a proper cinematic experience.

Definitely a must-watch for anyone who loves good cinema and strong performances.

summary.originalText: Probably the most realistic Indian spy thriller, simply loved it.

originalText.plaidHtml:
This isn't merely a movie, it feels like a gut punch of truth, a long overdue cinematic wake up call for India, from the moment the film begins.

Movie starts with the infamous hijacking of IC-814 which was taken to Kandhar Afganistan and follows up with the terror attack on the Indian Parliament, it makes you feel how incompetent we were and what's the mindset of these terrorists, and then from there on it grabs you by the collar and drags you deep into the world of covert terror networks the kind that operate across the border, lurking in the shadows, pulling strings from Pakistan. The brutality, the cold calculation, the lies it paints a chillingly realistic portrait of how these terrorists operate.

This film doesn't do the old Bollywood fireworks, it doesn't lean on exaggerated jingoism. Instead, it opts for gritty realism. The depiction of terror operations feels raw.

What made my jaw drop was the film's most explosive strand, when it's revealed that a minister and his son (movie hinted towards P Chidambaram) being linked to schemes that enabled fake currency to flood the country. The way the movie lays out this charge, the quiet transfers, the paper trails, the calculated betrayals. Watching it, I felt a cold morphological shift from disbelief to outraged clarity, the film insists we can't compartmentalize national security from the corridors of power.

Performances are electrifying, villains are frighteningly human and bureaucratic, amazing background score and themes for different characters, quite cool overall.

I feel if cinema is meant to provoke and make us look at uncomfortable truths, Dhurandhar succeeds spectacularly.

Controversial? Absolutely.

Brave? Undeniably.

Movie being of 3hrs 35mins doesn't feel long surprisingly. It's the kind of film that will be argued about for years, a cinematic blow that asks us not just to watch, but to reckon.

Eagerly waiting for the next part.

Loved every minute.o the movie and every character did justice to their role. I just want to watch the movie as many time as i can and desperately waiting for the second part in 3 months. Akshay khanna did justice to the movie and really happy for his comeback , ranveer sanjay dutt and arjun rampal were too good.

Dhurandar is a powerful true story that reflects India's strength, resilience, and capabilities. With gripping storytelling and impactful performances, it instills pride while keeping you thoroughly engaged. A must-watch. Mind blowing performance by Ranveer Singh and Akshay Khanna. Truly spectacular.

The way it keeps you hooked till the end needs to be studied.

summary.originalText: MUST WATCH CINEMA LIKE NEVER BEFORE

originalText.plaidHtml: üé¨ Experience cinematic history! This isn't just a movie; it's a monumental, sensory masterpiece. Prepare for a breathtaking spectacle that shatters expectations with revolutionary visuals, gripping soundscapes, and performances that will redefine your standards. A total immersion you must witness on the biggest screen possible. Forget everything you know about film-this is the future of storytelling. Don't just watch it; live it.

summary.originalText: A great Watch to understand the real stories

originalText.plaidHtml:
The director has showcased the real events and what happened before and after that.

No Tamasha - unnecessary love stories. Just as it happened.

Something our next generation shall watch and understand what used to happen, who are the players and so on.

Technically, "Dhurandhar" is on par with the best global cinema. The entire cast performs at an extraordinary level.

Verdict: A Perfect Film for the Ages "Dhurandhar" is the rare film that delivers on every promise and surpasses every expectation. It's a flawless piece of filmmaking-intelligent, impactful, and technically masterful. It challenges the viewer, leaves a lasting emotional mark, and will be studied for years to come. It is a perfect 10/10 and the undisputed Film of the Year. Do not miss this experience.

originalText.plaidHtml:
#Dhurandhar is the complete package of a movie. This is what the Indian audiance would like to see moving forward. #AdityaDhar has stablished a mile stone and gave a long time awaited action, emotional and full of patriotism package movie to #Bollywood. summary.originalText: Best movie i watch in bollywood Cinema

originalText.plaidHtml:
Beat acting best dialogues, everything I watched in this movie. That's a masterpiece as well as songs. Story line of movie also good. You must have to watch this movie in theatres after a long time I experience good nationalistic movie without any propaganda. Casting of the movie also is good.

And last aksha Khanna did great job.

Dhurandhar completely blew me away - and I actually did a bit of reading about the film beforehand so I wasn't just guessing: it's clearly rooted in real covert operations and inspired by real figures and events, which gives everything a heavier, more grounded feel than your usual glossy actioner, and I loved that about it; the movie doesn't chase a single over-the-top climax so much as it carefully unfolds - a relentless, realistic sequence of intelligence work, consequences, and human costs - and that slow-burn, documentary-ish weight made the whole thing feel way more authentic and intense to me. The cast is insane: everyone brings it - the leads and the smaller players - no weak links, and their chemistry and conviction kept me locked in even during the quieter stretches. Direction and production design make the world feel lived-in and dangerous, not stylised for show, and the score and camerawork ramp up tension without ever feeling manipulative. I came out of the theatre buzzing not because of a single jaw-dropping finale but because the film left me thinking about the moral grey areas it digs into and the real people it nods to; that's rarer than you'd expect in a big film. If you're after authentic spycraft framed like a human story more than a superhero spectacle, this is your movie - powerful, thoughtful, and properly acted. I genuinely enjoyed every minute and I'm already keen for whatever comes in the next sequel.

This is what an actual spy thriller must be like, REST OF THE BOLLYWOOD SHOULD TAKE NOTES.

Shame on the industry for feeding us low quality and mindless content for so many years, i have now seriously started doubting the patriotism of people making all the idiotic movies in disguise of patriotism, they don't even make movies for art it's purely commercial for them. But the way Aditya dhar has pulled this so well and has set a benchmark of patriotic movies is just unmatchable.

summary.originalText: A complete entertainment storm packed with unforgettable faces

originalText.plaidHtml: There's a relentless energy in the way the film unfolds, moving between intricate plotting and explosive action with seamless fluidity. Ranveer Singh's performance is layered and deeply human, capturing the subtle anxieties and decisive moments of his character. The supporting actors, from allies to adversaries, elevate the tension with nuanced portrayals. Director Dhar ensures that every scene serves both story and spectacle, combining masterful camera work, lighting, and score. The film's choreography, especially in fight sequences, is visceral without descending into chaos, making every action beat feel earned and essential to the narrative.

Movie is amazing not too much exaggerated and hero is shown under human limitations with a pinch of cinematic masala. Worth watching.

Songs are also good and quite intresting to listen All actors played great role no one is portrayed too much, everyone played their role perfectly upto the mark.

This movie is ideal movie on which bollywood should work on, no idealism, no too much drama stick to reality, show human limitations and human capacity.

summary.originalText: Dhurandhar: Undercover Fury in the Heart of Karachi's Chaos

originalText.plaidHtml:
What a rollercoaster! Aditya Dhar has outdone himself with Dhurandhar, crafting a spy thriller that's equal parts gritty gangster saga and high-octane espionage drama. Ranveer Singh as Hamza is a revelation-fierce, vulnerable, and utterly magnetic as the undercover Indian agent infiltrating Karachi's shadowy Lyari gang. His transformation from a mysterious drifter to a force tearing apart the ISI-underworld nexus feels raw and real, blending intense action sequences with those quiet moments of moral ambiguity that hit you hard.

The ensemble steals the show too: Akshaye Khanna oozes menacing charisma as Rehman Dakait, Sanjay Dutt brings that timeless gravitas in his limited but pivotal role, and R. Madhavan's Ajay Sanyal adds layers of strategic depth. Arjun Rampal and Sara Arjun round out the cast with solid support, keeping the emotional stakes sky-high. At 3+ hours, you'd think it'd drag, but the pacing is razor-sharp-every twist in the political intrigue and brutal fight scenes (those goosebump-inducing chases through Karachi's underbelly!) keeps you glued. The BGM, with clever nods to classic Bollywood tracks, amps up the immersion without overdoing it.

Sure, a few subplots feel a tad overstuffed, and the gore might turn off the faint-hearted, but this is bold, unapologetic cinema that resonates with real-world edge. A must-watch for thriller fans-leaves you craving that sequel tease at the end. Kudos to the tech team; the cinematography captures the chaos perfectly. One of 2025's best!

I walked out of the theater carrying the kind of quiet that follows a storm-the hush that comes after a film has shaken something loose inside you. Dhurandhar is that rare, unflinching work: a brave story told with the steadiness of someone who has seen the truth up close and refuses to look away. What makes it so gripping is its realism-not just in tone, but in texture. You feel the grit of the streets, the weight of decisions, the tension of rooms where history is being nudged, ever so forcefully, into focus. The story, inspired by real events, does not merely borrow from reality; it honors it. The integration of real footage is seamless and purposeful, never a gimmick or a shortcut. It acts like a spine running through the narrative, giving the film a raw nerve and undeniable authenticity. And yet, for all its documentary-like sincerity, the movie doesn't forget to breathe. It entertains-smartly, fiercely-drawing you in with craft and pacing, then challenging you with consequence. The acting is, simply, fabulous. Performances here aren't just "strong"-they are lived-in. You see it in the eyes before a word is spoken, in the small hesitations, in the way a hand grips a table edge when the weight of a choice becomes too heavy to carry. The lead turns in a performance that feels both heroic and human, while the supporting cast adds a chorus of voices that make the world of the film feel startlingly alive. Some critics, especially those viewing the film through a rigid ideological lens, seem to miss its core. This isn't a polemic; it's a portrait-of moral courage, of the costs paid by those who insist that truth be seen in the clear light of day. The film does not demand you agree with every choice its characters make; it asks only that you witness. And in witnessing, you feel. By the time the credits roll, Dhurandhar has done something rare: it leaves you stirred, not by spectacle alone, but by conviction. It's the kind of film that reminds you why stories matter-why we revisit painful histories, why we celebrate defiance, why we keep pushing for clarity in a world that so often rewards the fog. Watch it. Sit with it. Let it argue with you. And then, maybe, let it change you a little.
